intro.title: interactoMIX
intro.main:
The InteractoMIX platform is a combined effort of the Structural Bioinformatics and the Bioinsilico labs to bring together, and in a comprehensive manner, some of their current web applications.
Thus, it features a set of tools that addresses two major aspects of protein-protein interaction (PPIs) analysis:
  1. Which proteins interact. That is, the study of PPIs as a network of interactions.
  2. How proteins interact. That is, the structural details of an interaction.
The suite tackles some of the top interests in current biomedical research in a user-friendly and intuitive way. Both computational and experimental scientist can expand their knowledge on explicit pathways (in which their proteins of interest are involved), identify key residues related to the function of a particular interaction and, eventually, predict new therapeutic targets and other molecular agents.

SELECT AN APP FROM THE BULLSEYE TO START

biana.title: BIANA
biana.main: Biologic Interactions And Network Analysis is a biological database integration and network management framework. It uses a high level abstraction schema to define databases providing any kind of biological information (both individual entries and their relationships). Any data source that contains biologic or chemical data parsed by BIANA is defined as an external database, where both participants and relations are considered as external entities, characterized by several attributes. The power of BIANA relies in its unification protocol, a set of rules that determine how data in various data sources are combined, and its traceability, i.e. the attributes contained in each unified entity can always be traced back to its original source. This properties allow BIANA to offer the possibility to the user to create its own unification protocols, a feature missing in most of database unification frameworks.
biana.aim: The database is extremely usefull for those expecting to obtain the most complete interactome extracted from public databses and keep a constant track on the data sources.
biana.in: Once a new experiment is created, the user has to provide a list of protein identifiers as seeds to the requested PPI network. A part from that, the user can tweak several network and experimental related paramenters to further personalize the query. Finally, the user has to request for the specific attributes that wants to request with the search.
biana.out: BIANA provides the user with the network created from the query seed proteins according to the requested network attributes. Furthermore, it provides, for each entity and relation, all the extra data requested by the user. All the data can be downloaded and explored either visually or through applications shuch as Cytoscape.

bips.title: BIPS
bips.main: The interolog hypothesis implies that two proteins (A and B) are predicted to interact if a known interaction between two proteins (A’ and B’) exists, such that A is similar to A’ and B similar to B’. The BIANA Interolog Prediction Server offers a web interface to facilitate the prediction of PPIs based on interologs. The server benefits from the integration capabilities of BIANA to use a large data set of experimentally identified PPIs. Furthermore, it exploits additional information such as gene ontology (GO) terms, clusters of orthologous genes or taxonomy, which gives the user the freedom to restrict the predictions according to selected features.
bips.aim: The server is specially usefull to execute all vs. all interaction predictions between a set of query proteins.
bips.in: The user must provide a list of query proteins either in FASTA format or a list of standard protein identifiers.
bips.out:
The output is a list of predictions that can be viewed or downloaded. The user can browse the data associated with the predicted partners. The user can select several parameters helping estimate the reliability of the predictions such as:
  1. Sequence similarity measures.
  2. Domain–domain interactions.
  3. Common GO terms between the predicted partners.
  4. Clusters of orthologous genes for the prediction.
  5. Experimental method of the template interaction
  6. Taxonmy

iloops.title: iLoops
iloops.main: Based on ArchDB's classification of super-secondary structures (Smotifs), the iLoops Server exploits the funnel-like intermolecular energy landscape theory by mapping information of known PPIs and known non-interacting proteins (NPIs) to predict new protein-protein interactions.
iloops.aim: Assess the probability of a pair of proteins to interact or not interact.
iloops.in: The user must provide a set of FASTA protein sequences and up to 25 interactions to test. Complementary parameters can be selected depending on the user's interests.
iloops.out: For each requested protein-protein relation, the server provides a boolean prediction as if the relation is PPI or NPI. Furthermore, each prediction can be explored as to examine Smotif relations that statistically favour or disfavour the interaction.

guildify.title: GUILDify
guildify.main: GUILDify is a web server aiming to increase the understanding of the genes involved in various biological processes and disease phenotypes. Using BIANA, it combines the data available in the literature and GUILD's' graph-based guilt-by-association algorithms to rank genes in the interactome for their relevance to a phenotype of interest. For a given phenotype, it finds genes associated with the phenotype and ranks all other genes based on the connectedness to known disease-genes within the interactome, facilitating the discovery of novel disease-gene associations.
guildify.aim: The server is designed for biomedical researchers working either in dry or wet lab seeking an initial set of genes associated with a certain phenotype or a ranked list of genes potentially linked to the phenotype of interest.
guildify.in: The user needs only to provide keywords of their diesase of interest to the server and select the model species to search upon.
guildify.out: A table with the scores for all the nodes in the build network are provided together with an interactive vidalization of the network. All the data can be download for further study by the user.

modlink.title: ModLink<sup>+</sup>
modlink.main: ModLink+ allows an accurate prediction of a protein’s fold and structure. It combines advanced remote homology detection methods with known PPI data unified by BIANA and inferred PPI data from BIPS. Through the use of PPIs, ModLink+ is able to detect a correct structural template even at lower levels of sequence identity. It acts as a bridge between the interactome and the structural tools provided in the InteractoMIX suite.
modlink.aim: The main use of ModLink+ is to provide a series of structurally similar hits to a query protein and generate a three-dimensional model of its tertiary structure.
modlink.in: the user has to provide the FASTA formatatd sequence of the query protein, and select the preferred method to detect homology. Additionally, the user can also provide the FASTA sequences of other proteins known to interact with the query.
modlink.out: The server returns the models of the best structural domains that could be assigned to the query together with the corresponding lists of the PPIs that allowed assigning the different structural domains.

vorffip.title: VORFFIP
vorffip.main: The Voronoi Random Forest Feedback Interface Predictor Server is a structure-based computational method for the prediction of protein binding. It makes use of several residue features and a new definition of residue environment by means of Voronoi Diagrams that are integrated by a two-steps Random Forest predictor. The method scores the residues of protein structures and evaluates what regions are more likely to interact with other proteins.
vorffip.aim: VORFFIP is the tool of selection to predict protein surfaces that can be involved in protein-protein interactions.
vorffip.in: The basic input required is a PDB coordinate file. A part from that the user is able to tweak some paramenters in order to better fit their needs.
vorffip.out: A Jmol panel is given to the user mapping VORFFIP scores over the protein's surface. Furthermore, both the scores and a new coordinate file (PDB) with recalculated B-factors are provided to the user for download.

mvorffip.title: M-VORFFIP
mvorffip.main: Multi-VORFFIP is a structure-based, machine learning, computational method designed to predict protein-protein, protein-peptide, protein-DNA and protein-RNA binding sites. M-VORFFIP integrates a wide and heterogeneous set of residue- and environment-based information using a two-step Random Forest ensemble classifier.
mvorffip.aim: A typical use of M-VORFFIP is the prediction of functional sites for protein-, peptide-, DNA-, RNA-binding that can be used to guide experimental efforts such as functional mapping of sites in proteins or directed mutagenesis.
mvorffip.in: A simple PDB coordinate file is the only input required by the server.
mvorffip.out: Prediction scores for the residues of the protein and for each of the four binding targets are given to the user as well as Jmol representations for each one of them. All the produced data can be downloaded by the user for further study.

vdock.title: V-D<sup>2</sup>OCK
vdock.main: V-D2OCK is focused in the prediction of protein-protein complexes, designed to perform quaternary structure modelling at genome-wide interactome scale. The server uses the V-Patch algorithm to exploit VORFFIP's detection of protein-protein interfaces to guide PatchDock to perform directed dockings. Finally, the predicted poses are clustered in terms of their RMSD using the GROMOS algorithm
vdock.aim: The server is of interest for those users who, given the structure of two individual monomers, wants to model the quaternary structure of the protein complex. Its relative speed makes it specially interesting for those aiming for genome-wide studies.
vdock.in: V-D<sup>2</sup>OCK requires two PDB coordinate files to perform the docking. Additionally, the user can select extra scoring functions, the ability to add hidrogens to each structure and the tolerance to cluster decoys.
vdock.out: The server provides with tables detailing the predicted interaction sites as well as images of the best scored quaternary structures. As with the other servers, all the generated data can be downloaded by the user for further exploring.

pipred.title: PiPreD
pipred.main: The modulation of PPIs offers an enormous potential for the discovery of novel and important therapeutics and it is a the heart of renewed efforts in the biotech industry. PiPreD, is a novel, structure- and knowledge-based, approach to model the conformation of orthosteric peptides (those targeting protein interfaces). It relies on a library of structural motifs derived from interfaces and it uses native structural elements of the target-interface. The search and sampling of peptides covers the entire interface, systematic and comprehensive exploration without biases toward specific regions, thus the conformation of peptides is not biased.
pipred.aim: The more direct usage of the application relates to the design of peptides to target specific interactions in protein complexes. These peptides, once experimentally validated, can represent the starting point for the development of novel therapeutic agents or as lab reagents.
pipred.ext: Contrary to the rest of the tools in the InteractoMIX suite, the computational requirements of PiPreD makes it difficult to provide the service as a web-app. Thus, a guide is provided for the local installation of the software.

pcrpidb.title: PCRPi-DB
pcrpidb.main: As an extension to PCRPi-W, the PCRPi-DataBase lists all the annotated hot-spots predicted in known protein complexes in the Protein Data Bank. The database is weekly updated coinciding with the release of new protein structures in the PDB.
pcrpidb.aim: Beside the applications already described for described for PCRPi-W, PCRPi-DB can be also used in large-scale studies aimed to understand PPIs at interactome-level and derive common features.
pcrpidb.in: The repository can be browsed and queried in many different ways. Each one of them clearly stated in its help page.
pcrpidb.out: The structural information queried can be visualized using a bespoken molecular visualizer and a series of tables listing the data in a comprehensive manner.

pcpriw.title: PCPRi-W
pcpriw.main: The Presaging Critical Residues in Protein interfaces Webservice is a computational, machine-learning, approach designed to predict hot-spots, i.e. the residues with a large functional contribution, in protein interfaces. It relies in the integration of physical, sequence, and structural-based information that have been shown to better depict the nature of hot-spot residues.
pcpriw.aim: The tool is directed to users aiming to detect residues of interest for directed mutagenesis, structure-based protein design, or to derive chemicals mimicking critical residues in the interface.
pcpriw.in: The mandatory input is a PDB coordinate file of a protein-protein complex. This file can be either uploaded or directly picked from the Protein Data Bank. Some supplementary parameters can be tweaked in order to fit the user's needs.
pcpriw.out: Mutiple files are provided to the user. A part from the original PDB file, a remediated PDB file where quality checks have been perfomed and a B-factor substituted PDB file are provided. Files listing the atomic interactions at the interface of the selected chain and containing a list of predicted hot spot residues ranked by probability are also given to the user to download.
